comments.commentBody:
Professor Krugman,
Neoliberalism is a wide spectrum religious cult. I do not see a vast chasm between Mr. Cruz, Mr. Trump, Mrs Clinton or yourself. America has become a religion instead of a process as designed by the founders.
The failure to evolve a political process that allows the American people to feel that their government represents their interests has alienated all Americans even those who cleave to an extraordinarily inept former Secretary of State as their champion. America is now a country that now defines its citizens as who they are against. Evolution has made old ideologies obsolete driving cars in Beijing is killing children in Africa.
In 399 BC Socrates was sentenced to death because he understood what many Bernie Sanders supporters know to be the truth we know we are intelligent because we know that we know nothing.
Neoliberalism is the same as the the religion of ancient Athens. Bernie's crime is corrupting the youth and refusing to recognize the official gods of the state.
I suspect that 2016 will be the last time the United States will see a election where the three final candidates so well define the cornerstones of American society greed, power and corruption. I cannot conceive of any Western democracy where the candidates vying for the highest office in the land seem too comfortable speaking from the pulpit.
America came to be after Adam Smith and was supposed to have its people determine its destiny. America was to be the end of the invisible hand

Do you realize that less than 40% of voters consider themselves to be Democrats and usually less than half of them vote in the primaries? Which means that Sanders supporters represent something rather less than 10% of the total.
"While President Obama is in Germany attempting to push the TPP onto Merkel and the German''......TPP is an Asian trade agreement. Germany isn't part of Asia. Ok?
It is a great message, but Sanders has already been in Congress for 20 years or so and has accomplished....?

"I haven't seen anyone ask the question of what did Hillary Clinton accomplish as Senator?"....How many of Sanders Senate colleagues support his bit for President? One. How many support Clinton? Twenty - Thirty.  Sort of answers the question doesn't it.

Bernie Sanders the independent has spent his political career nurturing the small flame of the post-depression era Democratic Party’s traditions that the party itself has by default almost allowed to be snuffed out. Much of the party’s view of what kind of nation America should be was part of a governing consensus shared by Republicans as recently as Nixon and Ford. In today’s political spectrum, Nixon would not find a place in the GOP and would be to the left of the Democratic Party’s managers.

Hillary and the Democratic Party will make an historic mistake if they resist an inevitable shift of the pendulum back towards the left. I believe that once Hillary’s likely nomination becomes certain, Bernie should give her candidacy wholehearted support. But the Dems need to stand for something more than just not being the crazy party the other guys are.

If elected, Hillary could give a couple of good signals, one to inspire the nation and the other to inspire her party. On inauguration day she could tell Americans that, like FDR, she will be both a pragmatist and a President with big ideas – the two are not inconsistent. The next day she could start cleaning house at party HQ. DWS needs to step down in favor of someone who actually cares about a vision for the Democratic Party, not just its nuts and bolts.

Of course if the GOP wins, reshaping the Democratic Party will be all the more urgent.

‘’Write In’’ Bernie Sanders!
In November

Mark, it's not about whether I support Bernie or Hillary. Clearly, I support Bernie. But there's a strain of Democratic thought that has been decidedly muffled by the party leaders; now, with Bernie's help, it's coming back into the open because what worked in the 90s is no longer working. If Hillary and the rest of the party leaders are smart, they will understand this. If they don't, they will ultimately face the same turmoil that the Republicans find themselves in. Pragmatism alone does not inspire, and you will need inspiration of the voters to break the paralysis and deadlock of the past few years - in 2018, maybe.

I agree, FDR campaigned on big ideas but in office he was also a pragmatist. Hillary the pragmatist campaigner would be quite capable of governing with big ideas. This would not be reversing course, it would be confirming it.
Yes. And then "Write In" Trump's name right next to it...might as well, because you'll be swinging the vote in the Republican's favor anyway.

Eleanor, spent nuclear fuel is now stored safely and cleanly at over 100 locations in the U.S. It will soon be reused in Gen IV nuclear reactors to produce clean electricity, so no need to worry.

It would be beyond foolish to "dispose" of it. Spent fuel currently in storage holds enough energy to provide clean electricity to the entire world for over seventy years.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4UXXwWOImm8

ng114la, I'm looking at Chernobyl and more recently Fukushima, and I'm seeing a way to generate electricity that's not only the safest but the only way to keep from destroying the world's climate and oceans with fossil fuel carbon.
The idea that abundant "safe clean" energy is available from solar and wind is a lie - one that's been promulgated by the fossil fuel industry for the very purpose of doing away with nuclear energy for over fifty years. They won't succeed for two reasons: 1) the threat of climate change, and 2) enough people now know better.
https://newrepublic.com/article/132654/peoples-fission

ak, I live 20 miles downwind of the worst nuclear accident in U.S. history - the Santa Susana Field Laboratory Accident of 1959, which released ~400 times more radiation than Three Mile Island over the 1.77 million residents of Southern California's San Fernando Valley.

Never heard of it? Don't feel bad, most residents here haven't either. That was before "The China Syndrome" and a sensationalism-crazed news media kicked public imagination into high gear.

I urge the Democratic Party to incorporate some of Bernie Sanders' ideas into its 2016 platform and to unify Democrats at the 2016 convention. A $15 minimum wage and a ban on fracking, for example, are slam dunks.

The Democrats ignore Sanders and his supporters at their peril. Exclude them, and watch a new progressive party take root.

When slave states lost the election in 1860, they formed a new country. How is your proposal much different? you participate in a process, you lose and so you want to go off and pout by starting a new party?

Part of me thinks you should: you will see how tiny the Bernie party really is. The other part of me is amazed that Bernie supporters are such children and sore losers, that voting hasn't convinced you that the bulk of the country disagrees with you.

If Hillary is defeated by Trump, keep in mind that your new Progressive party will have to deal with at least two Trump- appointed Supreme Court justices who will throw the balance on the Court for possibly decades to come, when and if your party comes to power. Hillary's appointees would not be the same as Republican appointees, in terms of overturning Citizens United or restoring women's reproductive freedom. Progressives who stay home or write in protest candidates are playing a foolhardy game. And read the "if" in Koch's statement about Hillary. Not going to happen. He is playing you.

As a so called "Red State" resident, I strongly disagree that $15/hour is too much money for our workers. The need is even greater here, as will be the positive impact for both workers and the economy in general.
Somehow, my first choice - the Marvelettes' "Don't Mess with Bill" didn't fill the bill.
That was the first thing playing for me as well ...

"Mr. Sanders has tapped his two-million-person donor list to raise money for liberal congressional candidates in New York, Nevada and Washington State."

This is the first I've seen that mentioned in the NYT, despite seeing a flood of statements from Hillary's campaign of the opposite, that Bernie has not been doing that.

This is a serious failure of reporting.

I am on a fixed income and have contributed one month's income to support not only Bernie Sanders but other progressive Democratic candidates down ticket -- and I feel great about it. I have loved his approach to fund raising  -- for example dividing donations with down ticket candidates half and half.  I don't want my name going to the DNC however. Bernie don't give up those lists.

"possibly in response to the criticism"

So he was not asked. They just reported that he did not do it but that Hillary did.
He did it for 3 candidates who are running against other democrats. Not to turn any seat blue, but to primary existing dems, just like what the tea party does to repubs.

I always wonder what the agenda is of the increment of voters in open rather than closed primaries and caucuses.  Certainly the open variety could theoretically be used by opponents of the party to attempt to cause it to nominate a weaker candidate, but you have to wonder if the numbers make that likely.  Has anyone seen any research?

"the president’s housing secretary, Julián Castro, over his department’s sales of delinquent mortgages to banks and private equity firms"

Selling delinquent debt to vulture funds is the very extreme opposite of helping homeowners. First the banks won't compromise, and then the debt is sold at a steep discount to vultures who set out to ruin the debtor.

Julián Castro has been mentioned in the last few days as a likely prospect for Hillary as VP. Now I saw that Hillary was on the side of the banks, but I didn't imagine that would go so far as feeding homeowners to vulture funds.

That's not true.  Funds that buy mortgages are in it for a profit.  They realize that getting people to pay something is better than getting them to pay nothing.  A benefit of buying mortgages at a discount is that you don't take a loss if you accept less-than-full payments.  The government, on the other hand, is simply not in a position to work with delinquent mortgageowners to find a way of paying that works.  And it's worth pointing out that if the government loses, it's not just some nameless, faceless organization that loses: it's you, me, and everyone else that funds it.

Yep. It doesn't help "home owners" ... of course at the point that this debt is being sold calling them "owners" is more than a bit of a stretch, even though their names are likely still on the deed.

What is it you think the public should do about these mortgages? Please stop playing the left-wing version of the Republicans: the answer to everything being "no" without any plan or alternative proposal.

CLINTON/CASTRO 2016

"We promise to sell out the little guy!"

Party platforms are near meaningless.

Once Hillary has been crammed down for her agenda, there is no alternative but a new progressive party.

That is especially true if Hillary is defeated by Trump, as seems too likely. We have no need for two Republican Parties. We have no need for both parties that both appeal to the Koch Bros.

FDR campaigned that way. He did not launch it as a surprise in his Inaugural Address.

This proposes that Hillary ought to reverse course on her campaign, and govern entirely differently than she has said. That is unlikely.

If you want a President to do those things, support Bernie.

Which is the lesser evil? A right winger eccentric, or enabling the Dem Machine to settle the right its right wing onto us permanently as "less bad?"

For four years, things are going to be bad. What will we get for that?

With Trump, we'll get a Bush-like revulsion of Republicans and a new chance for Progressives.

With Hillary, we'd get her right wing cemented in place for a long time, as the only choice on offer -- right or further right.

The greater evil is a Hillary win.

W.A. Spitzer -- Do you realize that you are talking about the registered Dems of Hillary?

They are the 10% that is defying the clear desire of the Independents to get away from Machine party politics. It is Hillary supporters who represent something rather less than 10% of the total, by your theory.
He got the initials wrong, not the idea. He's pushing the TTIP agreement on Germany as we write. Large protests in Germany.

Might be good to notice that Sanders wins Caucuses, where a very small number of devoted followers can have a big impact. Sander supporters seem oblivious to the certainty that Sanders as President would not achieve his main stated objectives, he would be blocked more by Republicans, and conservative Democrats than Obama has been. Sanders is hurting the down ticket Democrats, as the general public will not so easily distinguish between the Robin Hood Sanders, and those Democrats on the down ticket.

Republican Primaries were meant for a face off between two candidates. Having two similar candidates splits their voters between the two, leaving a third candidate, whose views are less popular than the combined voters of the similar candidates can get all the electoral votes in Winner Take all States.

Might be good to notice that Sanders won 7.7 million votes, for about 42% of the total popular vote, meaning he has obviously not relied on a very small number of devoted followers.  Clinton supporters seem oblivious to the certainty that Clinton as President would not achieve her main stated objectives.  By projecting a centrist or center right doctrine to attract the widest possible support, she will assure a continued drift rightward of the nation.  She will hurt down ticket Democrats because blue dog democrats are largely a thing of the past and she doesn't inspire independents.  Look for her to pick a progressive or black running mate to counter this weakness by offering Sanders supporters a reason to vote, or retaining the edge of identity politics that Obama effectively used and rightly benefited from to counter discrimination and racism.
The reason is obvious though!  Clinton has a better DNA match with Cruz than with Trump or Sanders ...

"most dishonest, and egocentric woman in history." This statement is, of course, ridiculous. During this Presidential campaign, Politoco's fact checking shows her at 50% true or mostly true. Trump is at 9%. (The rest: Cruz at 22%, Sanders at 49%, Kasich at 52%.)
She has testified many times, she has been investigated by government and by the media many times, and there has never been a smoking gun uncovered.
Egocentricity is definitely in the eye of the beholder. With no objective measure for that trait, you can award her that title if you like.

His campaign only announced this support very recently,  possibly in response to the criticism that he's failed to help elect other like-minded candidates in all his many years of calling for a "revolution". Seems like a bit of an afterthought on his part to me.
@Nora: Excuse me, but David Koch is not openly supporting Hillary Clinton. Please watch the interview.

No that tells you how far the GOP has sunk. Even the Koch brothers are more concerned about the country than the GOP is today.

They just see her as better than Trump or Cruz. It does not seem to occur to you that just maybe those special interests find Cruz and Trump too extreme even for their conservative views. They see economic disaster under the GOP, it has a history of crashes and crisis.
